ygData.subject: New Artificial Life paper on automating evolution for physical robots
ygData.msgSnippet: Hi all, We re happy to announce a new paper in the Artificial Life Special Issue on the Evolution of Physical Systems by Andrés Faíña, Lars Toft Jacobsen,

Subject: New Artificial Life paper on automating evolution for physical robots
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=360532607; y=RIR6tXvJCRBZ9Y4hrZC95NR3nGbhu4vI1uGqVogANJ1mHc4v5Gzylb0
X-Yahoo-Profile: sebastian.risi
From: Sebastian Risi <sebastian.risi@...>

Hi all,

We're happy to announce a new paper in the Artificial Life Special=

Issue on the Evolution of Physical Systems by Andr=C3=A9s Fa=C3=AD=C3=B1a,=
 Lars Toft
Jacobsen, and Sebastian Risi titled "Automating the Incremental
=
Evolution of Controllers for Physical Robots".
We show that it is possible =
to fully automate the environmental setup
of an incremental evolutionary ex=
periment without human intervention,
via an industrial robot arm and marker=
-based computer vision system.
Through this system it is possible to evolve=
 mobile robots that can
perform simple obstacle avoidance without the need =
of a simulator.

Link: http://www.mitpressjournals.org/doi/abs/10.1162/ARTL=
_a_00226
PDF manuscript: http://sebastianrisi.com/wp-content/uploads/faina_=
2017alife.pdf

A video of the system in action can be found at: https://you=
tu.be/7kzw_cvqTIw

Abstract:
Evolutionary robotics is challenged with some =
key issues that must be
solved, or at least mitigated extensively, before i=
t can fulfill some
of its promises to deliver highly autonomous and adaptiv=
e robots. The
reality gap and the ability to transfer phenotypes from simul=
ation to
reality is one such problem. Another lies in the embodiment of the=

evolutionary processes which links to the first, but focuses on how
evolut=
ion can act on real agents and occur independent from simulation
i.e. going=
 from being =E2=80=9Cthe evolution of things, rather than just the
evolutio=
n of digital objects...=E2=80=9D[9]. The work presented here
investigates h=
ow fully autonomous evolution of robot controllers can
be realized in hardw=
are using an industrial robot and a marker-based
computer vision system. In=
 particular, this paper presents an approach
to automate the reconfiguratio=
n of the test environment and shows that
it is possible, for the first time=
, to incrementally evolve a neural
robot controller for different obstacle =
avoidance task with no human
intervention. Importantly, the system offers a=
 high level of
robustness and precision that could potentially open up the =
range of
problems amendable to embodied evolution.

Best,
Sebastian

-- 
Dr=
. Sebastian Risi
Associate Professor
IT University of Copenhagen, Room 5D12=

Rued Langgaards Vej 7, 2300 Copenhagen, Denmark
